itemDescription: former Scottish international football player and football manager, born 1958

wikipedia_page.main: Ian William Wilson (born 27 March 1958) is a former Scottish international football player and football manager.

response: **Ian Wilson (priest) (1920–1988), Dean of Argyll and The Isles

**Ian Wilson (footballer, born 1958), Scottish international football player

He joined Raith Rovers on a free transfer in April 1999, and made six appearances before the end of the season. After just a four-month stay at Stark's Park, he moved on to Stirling Albion. John Philliben's "Binos" finished seventh in the Second Division in 1999–2000; during the campaign McQuade scored a total of 16 goals in 41 games. He then left Forthbank Stadium and joined Ross County in July 2000. Neale Cooper's "Staggies" finished sixth in the First Division in 2000–01, as McQuade played 25 games. Having fallen out of the first team at Victoria Park, he moved on to Ian Wilson's Third Division side Peterhead in January 2002, before leaving Balmoor the following month.

After completing a pre-season campaign with Forfar Athletic in the summer of 2002, Manager Neil Cooper decided against signing Burns permanently, but recommended him to Peterhead Manager Ian Wilson who was delighted to sign him up for the 2002-03 season. This was a hugely enjoyable season for Burns, as he was an integral part of the team who were chasing the Balmoor side's first ever promotion, with the season ending in spectacular fashion as an incredible four sides went into the final day chasing the title. A 1–0 defeat away to Greenock Morton at a packed Cappielow saw Morton crowned champions and East Fife narrowly pip Peterhead to promotion.
